summary: This is a defense motion filed by Ghislaine Maxwell's attorneys, Mark S. Cohen and Christian R. Everdell, addressed to Judge Alison J. Nathan. The motion requests two forms of relief: (1) an order compelling the government to disclose the identities of the three alleged victims (Victims 1-3) referenced in the indictment to the defense, and (2) an order directing the Bureau of Prisons to improve Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) and grant her increased access to discovery materials to prepare her defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the filing attorneys, accused in the indictment. The motion argues for her right to a fair trial and improved detention conditions.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is representing Ghislaine Maxwell and is a signatory to this motion.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP who is representing Ghislaine Maxwell and is a signatory to this motion.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom this motion is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as the 'central figure' alleged to have engaged in misconduct with many victims. His prior detention and death are cited as the reason for Maxwell's harsh confinement conditions.

connections.description: Cohen is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this motion on her behalf.
Everdell is one of Maxwell's defense attorneys filing this motion on her behalf.
The document references Epstein as the 'central figure' and alleges Maxwell's involvement in the same misconduct. Civil suits have been filed against both.
Both are partners/attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP working together on Maxwell's defense.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell was arrested on the charges in the indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Arraignment and Bail Hearing
events.description: Court proceeding where the government indicated it would begin discovery production after a protective order was entered.

events.title: Protective Order Entered
events.description: The court entered a protective order governing the handling of discovery materials.

events.title: Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The government made its first Rule 16 discovery production, totaling nearly 13,000 pages, but did not identify Victims 1-3.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein's body was discovered in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was involved in an apparent suicide attempt while in custody.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007 (United States Courthouse)
keyFacts: The defense argues it cannot prepare a fair defense without knowing the identities of the three alleged victims (Victims 1-3) referenced in the indictment, as the alleged misconduct occurred roughly 25 years ago in multiple locations.

Ghislaine Maxwell is being held under uniquely harsh conditions at the MDC, including 24-hour surveillance, confinement outside general population beyond COVID quarantine, and severely limited access to discovery, which her attorneys attribute to the fallout from Jeffrey Epstein's death in custody.
The government's initial discovery production of nearly 13,000 pages did not identify Victims 1-3, and the defense argues waiting for full discovery would impair Maxwell's right to a fair trial.
The motion cites legal precedent, including United States v. Cannone and United States v. Warne, supporting pretrial disclosure of victim/witness identities when material to defense preparation.
The defense states that many alleged victims have already spoken publicly, filed civil suits, and given depositions, undermining government concerns about witness intimidation or refusal to testify.
